answer: The boys because their range is higher
ConstructName: Compare sets of data using the range
QuestionText:
The table shows the summary statistics from some girls and boys who took a test.
Who performed the most consistently? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Gender & Mean & Range \\
\hline Girls & \( 75 \) & \( 20 \) \\
\hline Boys & \( 60 \) & \( 40 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks a greater range means more consistent data

ConstructName: Recognise the notation for parallel lines
QuestionText: Tom and Katie are discussing parallel lines. Tom says these two lines are parallel ![Image of a grid of squares with 2 lines on it. One line goes two squares to the right and one square up. The second line goes four squares to the right and two squares up.]() Katie says these two lines are parallel ![Image of a grid of squares with 2 lines on it. One line goes two squares to the right and one square up. The second line goes two squares to the right and one square down.]() Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes two lines of the same length are parallel

ConstructName: Carry out subtraction problems involving two negative integers
QuestionText:
What number belongs in the box?
\(
(-8)-(-5)=
\square\)
MisconceptionName: When subtracting from a negative thinks the answer must be positive

ConstructName: Use brackets to write function machines as calculations
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are arguing about the result of this Function Machine:
Jo says the output is: \( \frac{n}{5}+3 \)
Paul says the output is: \( \frac{n+3}{5} \)
Who is correct? ![A function machine showing an input of n and operations divide by 5 and add 3]()
MisconceptionName: Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.

ConstructName: Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form ax² + bx + c
QuestionText:
\(
6,14,28,48,74, \ldots
\)

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the triangle?

nth-term rule: \( 3 n^{2} \)\( \color{red}\triangle \)  \(n\) \( \color{purple}\square \)
MisconceptionName: When finding the nth term rule for a quadratic sequence, believes they only need to use the first term to calculate the coefficient of n

ConstructName: Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about solving inequalities.
Tom says \( -2 m>12 \) gives \( m>-6 \)
Katie says \( -2+m>12 \) gives \( m>14 \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes they can multiply/divide through by a negative number without changing the direction of the inequality

ConstructName: Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure
QuestionText:
\(
0.095643
\)

What is this number rounded to \( 1 \) significant figure?
MisconceptionName: When rounding up from a 9, does not add one on to the digit to the left

ConstructName: Carry out multiplication problems involving one negative integer
QuestionText:
The product of two numbers is \( -24 \).
What could the two numbers be?
MisconceptionName: Believes that product means add rather than multiply

ConstructName: Read values from piecewise functions
QuestionText:
Tom is has correctly drawn the graph of the following function:
\(
y=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
3 \text { for } 0 \leq x<Q \\
P \text { for } 1.5 \leq x<4 \\
2.5 \text { for } 4 \leq x<7
\end{array}\right.
\)

What are the values of \( P \) and \( Q \) ? ![The graph is three separate horizontal lines. It goes from (0,3) to (1.5, 3), then (1.5, 2) to (4, 2) and the last section is from (4, 2.5) to (7, 2.5)]()
MisconceptionName: When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately

ConstructName: Multiply mixed number fraction in the form: Fraction × Fraction
QuestionText: \( 1 \frac{1}{2} \times 3 \frac{2}{3}=\bigstar\frac{3}{6} \) What should replace the star?
MisconceptionName: When multiplying mixed numbers thinks they add the integers

ConstructName: Identify a unit of volume or capacity
QuestionText: Which of the following is not a measure of volume?
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise litres as a unit of volume

answer: To get the next term you double the previous term and add \( 2 \)
ConstructName: Describe a term-to-term sequence
QuestionText: Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence? \( 4, \quad 10, \quad 14, \quad 24, \quad \ldots \)
MisconceptionName: Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule

ConstructName: Round integers to the nearest 10
QuestionText: What is \( 5050 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)

ConstructName: Calculate time where speed and distance are in the appropriate units
QuestionText:
This displacement-time graph shows the start of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).
What are the coordinates of the marked point? ![The vertical axis of the graph is labelled Distance (m) and has a scale marked from 0 to 60 in even steps. The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has no scale marked on it. The graph is a straight line that goes from point (0,60) and touches the Time axis three squares from the origin (0,0).
The marked point is one square in on the Time axis and at 40 on the Distance axis.]()
MisconceptionName: Makes an assumption about the squares on a scale representing either 1 or 10

ConstructName: Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: When calculating the area of this trapezium, what are the values of \( a \) and \( b \) in the formula? ![Diagram of a trapezium with its 2 parallel sides horizontal. The parallel sides are labelled as 9cm and 10cm. The lengths of the 2 non-parallel sides are labelled as 7cm and 7.5cm. The perpendicular height is labelled as 6cm.]() Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \)
MisconceptionName: Uses slant heights instead of parallel sides to find area of a trapezium

ConstructName: Calculate the range from a list of data

MisconceptionName: Finds the mean instead of the range

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b)
QuestionText:
The area of the trapezium on the right is \( 40 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled with x+2 and x+4 and the perpendicular height x.]() Based on the information given, Adam writes this formula:
\(x^{2}+3 x=40\)

What are the two solutions to this equation?
MisconceptionName: Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the constants in the factorised form

ConstructName: Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one
QuestionText: Without drawing any more terms, how many circles do you predict will be in the \( 7 \) th term of this sequence? ![A diagram showing the first 3 patterns in a sequence. Pattern 1 is a rectangle with a total of 6 circles surrounding it. Pattern 2 is 2 rectangles with a total of 10 circles surrounding it. Pattern 3 is 3 rectangles with a total of 14 circles surrounding it.]()
MisconceptionName: When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after

ConstructName: Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data

What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
3,5,6,18,18,-4
\]
MisconceptionName: When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle

ConstructName: Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: What is the area of this triangle? ![A right angled triangle with base length 11cm, slant height, 13 cm and perpendicular height 8cm.]()
MisconceptionName: Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area

ConstructName: Triple numbers
QuestionText: If you triple \( 8 \) you get...
MisconceptionName: When asked to triple, writes the digit out three times

ConstructName: Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions
MisconceptionName: Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets

ConstructName: Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols

MisconceptionName: When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1

ConstructName: Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule

What is the first term of the sequence with the nth-term rule:
\[
5 n-7
\]

Tom and Katie are arguing about the diagonals of quadrilaterals.

Who is correct? ![A pair of intersecting lines]()

ConstructName: Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c

What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
MisconceptionName: Believes the square of a negative will also be negative

MisconceptionName: Multiplies by the denominator instead of dividing when finding a fraction of an amount

answer: ![An incorrect completion of the figure given in the question. ]()

QuestionText: Which image completes a symmetric figure using the red line of symmetry? ![A figure drawn in the upper half of a box with a red dotted line immediately below. ]()

QuestionText: Which of the following triangles have the same area as this rectangle? ![Rectangle with base 7 and height 3]()

\hline \( 8 \) & \( 3 \) \\

Sarah has some apples.

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText: Tom and Katie are arguing about how to reflect the object in the line of reflection. Who reflects it correctly? ![A grid with a left-leaning parallelogram drawn in the upper half and a blue line across the middle, marked 'line of reflection'. ]() ![Tom does this: an image of a grid with a left-leaning parallelogram drawn in the upper half, a blue line across the middle and a left-leaning parallelogram drawn immediately below. ]() ![Katie does this: An image of a grid with a left-leaning parallelogram drawn in the upper half, a blue line across the middle and a left-leaning parallelogram drawn one line down from the blue line. ]()

\]

\[

204050
\)

\(
x(3 x-5)+6(2 x-3) \equiv P x^{2}+Q x+R
\)

MisconceptionName: Believes you can add or subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation

\(
a+6+a+j+5+j+j
\)

Katie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}-\mathbf{3} \) are parallel.

Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes switching the gradient and y-intercept gives a parallel line

\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
MisconceptionName: Believes the mode is the frequency rather than the value/group

What are the new coordinates of the point marked \( T \) ? ![A coordinate grid with the x-axis going from -1 to 10 and the y-axis going from -1 to 7.
3 points are plotted and joined with straight lines to form a triangle. The points are (1,1), (1,4) and (3,1). Point (3,1) is labelled as T.
Point (1,0) is also plotted.]()
MisconceptionName: Added rather than multiplied by a scale factor

\]

\[
y=0.5 x-2
\]

\[
0.5 x-2=1
\] ![Graph showing straight line with y intercept (0,-2) and x intercept (4,0)]()
MisconceptionName: Believes the solution to mx + c = a is the x intercept of y = mx +c

ConstructName: Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative

\( M \) is the midpoint between points \( P \) and \( Q \).

Tom says if you know the location of \( M \) only, then there is more than one possible location for \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \).

Katie says if you only know the locations of \( M \) and \( Q \), then there is more than one possible location for \( \mathrm{P} \).
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes there is more than one line which passes through a given pair of points

Pattern 3 contains 7 squares in this arrangement :::.]()

answer: ![A straight line graph that crosses the x axis to the left of the origin and crosses the y axis above the origin.]()

(p-3)(p+3) \equiv p^{2} \color{purple}\triangle\) \(p\)\(\color{green}\bigcirc
\)

QuestionText: The two lines marked are... ![Trapezium with parallel sides labelled]()
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise the notation for parallel sides

ConstructName: Describe the properties of a rhombus
QuestionText:
\( A B C D \) is a rhombus.
Which lines must be perpendicular? ![Tilted rhombus with top left vertex labelled A, top right vertex labelled B, bottom left vertex labelled D and bottom right vertex labelled C.]()
MisconceptionName: Confuses the meaning of parallel and perpendicular

ConstructName: Given a line segment, calculate the gradient where the gradient is a positive integer
QuestionText: What is the gradient of this line? ![A set of axes with a graph drawn on. The graph passes through the following points: (-3,-3) (-2,-2) (-1,-1) (0,0) (1,1) (2,2) and (3,3).]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks the gradient of a line includes the variable x

ConstructName: Write 5 digit numbers and above as words
QuestionText:
How do you write this number in words?

\( 60302 \)
MisconceptionName: Confuses the hundreds and tens place value columns

ConstructName: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed
QuestionText: Rearrange the following equation to make \( \omega \) the subject \( F=r \omega^{2} \)
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.

ConstructName: Divide mixed number fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer
QuestionText:
\(
2 \frac{2}{3} \div 2
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
MisconceptionName: When the dividend is a mixed number and the divisor is an integer, thinks they only divide the fraction by the integer.

ConstructName: Identify a unit of time
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing units of time 
Tom says days is a unit of time 
Katie says \( \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{h} \) is a unit of time 
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Mistakes unit of speed for unit of time

ConstructName: Substitute negative integer values into formulae involving powers or roots
QuestionText:
\(
F=3^{a}
\)

What is the value of \( F \) when \( a=-5 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Has multiplied the base number and the power

ConstructName: Multiply 3 digit integers by 1 digit integers using long multiplication
QuestionText:
Charlotte is trying to solve this problem using long multiplication.

What should replace the star as the tens digit in her final answer? \( 538 \times 7 \) \begin{tabular}{r|r|r|r|}
\(\space\) & \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\( \times \) & \(\space\) & \(\space\) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\bigstar\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
MisconceptionName: Tries to multiply within place value columns during column multiplication

ConstructName: Prove statements involving positive and negative numbers
QuestionText: Which of these could be used as a counter - example to disprove Katie's theory that \( 2 n^{2}-1 \) is positive?
MisconceptionName: Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer

ConstructName: Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of both expressions
QuestionText:
What is the value of \( l \) in these simultaneous equations?
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 l+3 m=13 \\
3 l+4 m=17
\end{array}
\)
MisconceptionName: Believes subtraction is commutative

ConstructName: Represent an equation using a bar model
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing bar models. Tom says this bar model represents \( 5 x \) \begin{tabular}{l|l}
\hline \( 5 \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Katie says this bar model represents \( 5 x \) \begin{tabular}{l|l|l|l|l|}
\( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Who do you agree with?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand bar modelling in algebra

ConstructName: Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons
QuestionText: Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons Tom says this is a regular polygon: ![A rhombus]() Katie says this is a regular polygon: ![A rectangle]() Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that all angles and sides must be equal for regular shapes

ConstructName: Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c
QuestionText:
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(
y=x^{2}-1
\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
MisconceptionName: Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation

ConstructName: Use common conventions for labelling the sides of shapes
QuestionText: Which of the following is a correct way to describe the highlighted side of this shape? ![A  4 sided shape with two pairs of parallel sides. Each vertex (corner) is labelled with a letter. The bottom right is S, the bottom left is P, the top left is Q and the top right is R. The side joining P and Q is highlighted in red.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not know the correct notation for labelling a side length

ConstructName: Multiply algebraic terms, involving non-linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a2 x 5ab)
QuestionText: \( 5 p^{2} \times 2 p q \equiv \)
MisconceptionName: Adds instead of multiplies when multiplying algebraic terms

ConstructName: Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number
QuestionText:
\begin{tabular}{llllll}
\( \frac{2}{10} \) & \( \frac{9}{50} \) & \( \frac{9}{20} \) & \( 0.21 \) & \( \frac{1}{5} \) & \( \frac{19}{100} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
MisconceptionName: Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values

ConstructName: Find missing angles using angles around a point
QuestionText: What is the size of angle \( x \) ? ![Angles around a point, split into 2 parts. One is labelled 310 degrees and the other x.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not know that angles around a point sum to 360

ConstructName: Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator
QuestionText:
Write the following as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{(x+3)(x+5)}{(x+3)(x+10)}
\)
MisconceptionName: Expands when asked to simplify

ConstructName: Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The height is 4cm, the depth is 3cm and the width is 6cm.]()
MisconceptionName: When calculating surface area, only includes visible faces

ConstructName: Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division
QuestionText:
Problem P: \( 4-5+6= \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5 \times 6= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
MisconceptionName: Performs addition ahead of any other operation

answer: \( 82 \) is not in the sequence because \( 27 \) is an integer
ConstructName: Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not
QuestionText:
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
MisconceptionName: Believes the position of a sequence cannot be an integer

ConstructName: Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator
QuestionText: Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{t^{2}+2 t+1}{t+1} \)
MisconceptionName: Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator

ConstructName: Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction
QuestionText: Which calculation gives the fraction that replaces the question mark? ![A horizontal bar divided into 4 equal sections with vertical lines. The left hand section of these is coloured green and is further divided into 2 equal sections with vertical dotted lines. A curly bracket shows that the width of one of these green sections is denoted by a question mark.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not understand parts must be equal in a fraction diagram

ConstructName: Convert the reminders from written division problems into decimals
QuestionText:
John has been asked to work out the answer to:
\[
232 \div 5
\]
He gets the answer \( 46 \) remainder \( 2 \)
What is the exact value of that remainder?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand remainders in division

ConstructName: Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures
QuestionText: Which of the numbers is the same when rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places or to \( 2 \) significant figures?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand the first significant value is the first non-zero digit number

ConstructName: Add decimals with the same number of decimals places
MisconceptionName: When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit

ConstructName: Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places
QuestionText:
What should replace the star?
\(
0.3 \div \bigstar=1.2
\)
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation, multiplies instead of dividing

ConstructName: Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(cx + d)
QuestionText:
Alison is expanding these two brackets.

What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The two brackets are (5p-4)(2p-3). The arrows are pointing at the 5p in the first bracket and the -3 in the second bracket.]()
MisconceptionName: Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket

ConstructName: Multiply a decimal by an integer
QuestionText:
Work out:
\[
0.3 \times 12
\]
MisconceptionName: When multiplying a decimal less than 1 by an integer, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c
QuestionText: Factorise \( x^{2}+15 x+36 \) Factorise \( x^{2}+15 x+36 \)
MisconceptionName: Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant

ConstructName: Identify the number of degrees in fractions of a turn
QuestionText: How many degrees are there in \( 1 \frac{1}{4} \) full turns?
MisconceptionName: Believes there are 100 degrees in a full turn

ConstructName: Round non-integers to the nearest 10
QuestionText: What is \( \mathbf{9 9 9 . 9 9 9} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
MisconceptionName: Rounds down instead of up

ConstructName: Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other
QuestionText:
Calculate:
\(
\frac{2}{9}+\frac{1}{3}
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not consider the denominator when adding/ subtracting fractions. Adds/subtracts the numerator and makes the denominator the one with the highest value.

ConstructName: Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 0.1-0.2 \div 0.3 \equiv 0.1-(0.2 \div 0.3) \)
Katie says: \( 0.1-0.2 \div 0.3 \equiv 0.2 \div 0.3-0.1 \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Performs subtraction right to left if priority order means doing a calculation to the right first

ConstructName: Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators
QuestionText:
\(
2 \frac{2}{5}-\frac{1}{15}=2 \frac{1}{\bigstar}
\)
What should replace the star?
MisconceptionName: Believes when simplifying a fraction you can divide the numerator and denominator by different values

ConstructName: Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x}{3}-5=12
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{3}=17 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( x-5=36 \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount

ConstructName: Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places
MisconceptionName: Believes you subtract the smaller digit from the larger digit in column subtraction, regardless of position

ConstructName: Represent positive unit fractions on a number line
QuestionText:
The probability of picking a green ball is \( \frac{1}{5} \) Where is this value on the probability scale? ![B
c
D]()
MisconceptionName: Converts a fraction to a decimal by using the denominator after the decimal point

ConstructName: Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols
QuestionText:
![A pictogram where one smiley face =8 people. Game 1 has 4 faces. Game 2 has 3 faces. Game 3 has 2 faces. Game 4 has 2.75 faces.]() The pictogram shows the number of people who went to watch a netball match.
How many people went to game 4?
MisconceptionName: When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1

ConstructName: Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers
QuestionText: Complete the statement \( \frac{4}{6}=\frac{}{12} \)
MisconceptionName: Believes equivalent fractions are formed with addition not multiplication

ConstructName: Recognise and name a term
QuestionText: Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe \( 3 g \) in this: \( 6-3 g \)
MisconceptionName: Confuses a term with an equation

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
The triangle is reflected in the \( y \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -2 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, -2), (4, -2), (3, -1). Point (3, -1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
MisconceptionName: Fails to reflect across mirror line

ConstructName: Identify a rectangle when presented non-conventionally
QuestionText: What shape do you get if you join up the midpoints of the sides of this shape? ![An irregular quadrilateral drawn on a grid]()
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise the properties of a kite

ConstructName: Convert ratios to fractions
QuestionText:
Kate and Isaac share some yoghurt in the ratio \( 2: 5 \).
Kate has \(_____\) of the total yoghurt
What fraction completes the sentence?
MisconceptionName: When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total

ConstructName: Carry out multiplication problems involving two negative integers
QuestionText: Which calculation is incorrect?
MisconceptionName: Believes multiplying two positives gives a negative answer

ConstructName: Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1
QuestionText:
The probability of an event occurring is \( \frac{2}{7} \).

What is the probability of the event not occurring?
MisconceptionName: Gives probability as an integer instead of a fraction

ConstructName: Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: What is the area of this shape? ![Parallelogram drawn on square grid with area of 6 squares]()
MisconceptionName: Underestimates the area of shapes when counting squares when some squares are neither wholes nor halves

ConstructName: Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers
QuestionText: What number is the arrow pointing to? ![A number line from 100 to 200 with an arrow pointing to the value 160]()
MisconceptionName: When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 1

ConstructName: Identify a transversal
QuestionText:
Line \( X Y \) is... ![A pair of parallel lines are drawn with the arrows pointing up to the left.
A straight red line, XY, is drawn so that it diagonally crosses the pair of parallel lines. The red line rises from X on the left up to Y.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not know the term transversal

ConstructName: Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers
MisconceptionName: Multiplies by the index

ConstructName: Create a situation to match an algebraic expression
QuestionText:
Which model does not correctly represent the following expression?
\(2(n+3)\)
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise the distributive property

ConstructName: Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons
QuestionText: Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons. Tom says this is a regular polygon ![A triangle with 3 equal sides and 3 equal angles]() Katie says this is a regular polygon ![A parallelogram with 2 pairs of parallel sides marked]() Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not know the meaning of the word regular

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
![A grid of 7 squares across and 7 squares up. A red vertical line goes from the bottom to the top of the grid, it is 4 squares left from the edge of the grid. An orange rectangle (3 squares width and 2 squares height) is drawn to the left of the red line, with its right-hand side on the red line.  The bottom side of the rectangle is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid. The bottom left corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter P, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid and 3 squares to the left of the red line. The bottom right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter Q, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. ]() Tom and Katie are discussing reflections

Tom says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( P \) stays in the same position

Katie says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( Q \) stays in the same position
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Fails to reflect across mirror line

ConstructName: Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{m}{6}-4=24
\)
Jo says you can write: \( \frac{m}{6}=28 \)
Paul says you can write: \( m-4=144 \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation with a fraction, thinks you don't need to multiply every term on both sides when multiplying by the denominator

ConstructName: Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object
QuestionText: John rotates rectangle \( A B C D 90^{\circ} \) clockwise from the centre \( (3,2) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two rectangles drawn on it. The rectangle labelled ABCD has the coordinates: A(1,3) B(1,5) C(2,5) and D(2,3). The other rectangle has the coordinates: (4,3) (6,3) (6,2) and (4,2).]()
MisconceptionName: Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point P? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (2, 2) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=2 is shown with a purple dashed line.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected

ConstructName: Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place
QuestionText:
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\(
0.4, \quad \frac{1}{4}, \quad 2.5, \quad \frac{2}{5}
\)
MisconceptionName: Converts a fraction to a percentage by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator

ConstructName: Given an equation, form  or identify related equations
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are talking about statements that can be made about the equation on the right. \( 2 x=y \) Jo says this is always true: \( 2 x+1>y \) 
Paul says this is always true: \( -2 x<y \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes -a is always smaller than a, ignoring the possibility that a is negative

ConstructName: Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages
MisconceptionName: Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage

ConstructName: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed
QuestionText:
The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is
\(A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h)\)

Rearrange this to make the height, \( h \), the subject. ![An image of a triangle with the base labelled b and the perpendicular height h.]()
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.

ConstructName: Identify parallel lines with at least one equation written in another form
QuestionText:
Which of the following lines is not parallel to
\[
y=-2 x+7 \text { ? }
\]
MisconceptionName: When given the equation of a straight line, believes the first term always gives the gradient, even when the first term is actually c

ConstructName: Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms
QuestionText:
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{t}{2}
\)
MisconceptionName: When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators

ConstructName: Reduce a ratio involving two numbers to its simplest form
QuestionText:
Write the following ratio in its simplest form so both sides of the ratio are integers:
\(
\frac{1}{8}: \frac{1}{2}
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not fully simplify ratio

ConstructName: Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a decimal
MisconceptionName: Does not understand a percentage can be applied to something not out of 100

ConstructName: Follow simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors
QuestionText: If you translate the star \( 3 \) squares left and \( 2 \) squares down, which letter do you land on? ![Positive coordinate grid from 0 to 8 in the x and y directions with a gold star at (4,4), A at (7,2), B at (2,1), C at (2,2) and D at (1,2)]()
MisconceptionName: When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.

answer: ![A straight line, separated into three angles. One is unmarked, one is 90 degrees and one is 45 degrees]()
ConstructName: Recognise the angles on a straight line relationship
QuestionText: Which of the following cannot represent a straight line?
MisconceptionName: Misinterprets the meaning of angles on a straight line angle fact

ConstructName: Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one
QuestionText:
These two shapes are similar (not drawn to scale).
What should replace the star? ![Two scalene triangles. The smaller one has sides 5cm and 4cm. On the bigger triangle, the side corresponding to the 5cm is 15cm, and the side corresponding to the 4cm is marked with a star.]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks adding the same value to each side makes shapes similar

ConstructName: Count backwards through zero starting from a positive integer
QuestionText:
John's flat is on floor \( 4 \).

The gym is on floor \( -1 \).

How many floors does John need to go down to get from his flat to the gym? ![A vertical number line from -8 to 7 increasing in 1 digit increments]()
MisconceptionName: Counts the starting number when counting backwards

ConstructName: Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots
QuestionText:
When \( h=10 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
MisconceptionName: Multiplies before applying a power

ConstructName: Round numbers to one decimal place
QuestionText: \( 58.2684 \) to \( 1 \) decimal place is....
MisconceptionName: Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values

ConstructName: Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information
QuestionText: \( \begin{array}{c}\xi=\{\text { integers between } 1 \\ \text { and } 10 \text { inclusive }\} \\ P=\{\text { odd numbers }\} \\ Q=\{\text { factors of } 30\}\end{array} \) ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled P and Q. P without the intersection is labelled A, Q without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]() In which region does \( \mathbf{5} \) belong?
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise that the intersection of a Venn diagram represents those belonging to both sets

ConstructName: Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction
QuestionText:
Simplify fully (if possible):
\(
\frac{13}{78}
\) Simplify fully (if possible): \( \frac{13}{78} \)
MisconceptionName: Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator

ConstructName: Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing sequences
Tom says \( (\boldsymbol{n}+\mathbf{1})^{3} \) would produce a linear sequence.
Katie says \( 3-\frac{n}{3} \) would produce a linear sequence
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount

ConstructName: Find missing angles using angles on a straight line
QuestionText: What is the size of angle \( q \) ? ![A long straight line with two shorter lines joining it, but not crossing it. Where the line on the left joins it forms two angles, q on the left, 126 degrees on the right. Where the line on the right joins it forms two angles, the left is unmarked, 37 degrees on the right.]()
MisconceptionName: Misinterprets the meaning of angles on a straight line angle fact

ConstructName: Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition
QuestionText:
Nick wants to add \( 97 \) to a number.
Which one of the following methods would give him the correct answer?
MisconceptionName: Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems

ConstructName: Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain
QuestionText:
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0.9 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that a probability of 1 represents something that is certain

ConstructName: Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: What is the area of this triangle? ![A right angled triangle with base length 12 cm, slant length 15cm and perpendicular height 9cm.]()
MisconceptionName: Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area

ConstructName: Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number
QuestionText: \( \begin{array}{llllll}\frac{8}{10} & \frac{41}{50} & \frac{7}{20} & 0.77 & \frac{4}{5} & \frac{79}{100}\end{array} \) Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
MisconceptionName: Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values

ConstructName: Convert from days to seconds
QuestionText: Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 2 \) days?
MisconceptionName: Converted hours to minutes instead of hours to seconds

ConstructName: Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving positive fractions
QuestionText:
Solve the equation:
\(
p-3=\frac{1}{12}
\)
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation, multiplies instead of adding

ConstructName: Substitute into simple formulae given in words
QuestionText:
To work out the area of a triangle you multiply the base by the perpendicular height and then halve your answer.
What is the area of this triangle? ![Triangle with base b=5cm and perpendicular height h=3cm]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks halving is the same as multiplying by 2

ConstructName: Calculate the square of a number
QuestionText: What is the value of \( 4^{2} \) ?
MisconceptionName: Adds the index to the number

ConstructName: Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph
QuestionText:
The graph shows information about the velocity, \( v \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), of a parachutist \( t \) seconds after leaving a plane.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \( t=6 \) ![The image is of a velocity-time graph. There is a straight line, a tangent, drawn so that it is touching the curve at t=6. The tangent goes through (2, 31), (6, 47) and (8,55). ]()
MisconceptionName: Believes gradient at a point = y coordinate/x coordinate

ConstructName: Recognise other roots of numbers
MisconceptionName: Divides by the order of the root

ConstructName: Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c
QuestionText:
What is the gradient of this line?
\(4 x-5 y=20\)
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value

ConstructName: Read values off a real life graph
QuestionText:
This is a conversion graph between pints and litres.
Which of the following is the best estimate for the number of pints equivalent to \( 50 \) litres? ![A graph on gridded paper showing litres on the y axis from 0 to 50 and pints on the x axis from 0 to 90. A straight line goes from the origin and passes through (35,20) (not marked - just a point it goes through) but extends the whole way up the graph.]()
MisconceptionName: When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.

ConstructName: Given a positive y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c
QuestionText: This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( y=3 x \) ![A table with two rows and two columns. The top left box has 'x', with a star in the top right box. The bottom left box has 'y' with a 9 in the bottom right box. ]() What should replace the star?
MisconceptionName: Mixes up the value of two terms when substituting

ConstructName: Identify data which is qualitative or quantitative
QuestionText:
Leanne has written a questionnaire on the topic of holidays. One of her questions is,

"Describe how you feel when you are about to go on holiday."

What type of data is she collecting by asking this question?
MisconceptionName: Does not know the meaning of attribute data

ConstructName: Answer negative number problems that require the use of BIDMAS
QuestionText: Which calculation is equal to \( -20 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer

ConstructName: Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about the order of rotational symmetry of quadrilaterals.

Tom says some quadrilaterals have an order of rotational symmetry of \( 1 \).
Katie says some quadrilaterals have an order of rotational symmetry of \( 3 \).
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not connect rotational symmetry to number of sides/vertices

ConstructName: Read a negative integer temperature from a thermometer
QuestionText: What temperature does the thermometer show? ![A thermometer showing the temperature in degrees Celsius. There are five steps on the scale between 10 and 0, and five steps between 0 and -10. The temperature is shown at 4 steps below 0.]()
MisconceptionName: When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 1

ConstructName: Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method
QuestionText:
What should replace the star when solving the following problem using the grid method?
\(52 \times 326\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 300 \) & \( 20 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 50 \) &  &  \( \bigstar \) & \\
\hline \( 2 \) &  & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
MisconceptionName: Adds instead of multiples

ConstructName: Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information
QuestionText: In which region would \( \mathbf{3 6} \) belong? ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Square number and one labelled Odd number. Square Number without the intersection is labelled A, Odd Number without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]()
MisconceptionName: Mixes up odd and even numbers

ConstructName: Complete missing number mental addition problems with numbers over 1000
QuestionText:
A \( 3 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
258+\square=1162
\)
What is the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
MisconceptionName: Subtracts the smallest digit from the largest digit

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
A point, \( Q \), has coordinates \( (2,5) \)
The point is reflected in the line \( x=2 \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ?
MisconceptionName: Thinks x = ? or y = ? is y = x

ConstructName: Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots
QuestionText:
When \( h=5 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
MisconceptionName: Multiplies before applying a power

ConstructName: Given the description of an algebraic term with powers, write the term using algebra
QuestionText: Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( m \) multiplied by the cube of \( n \)
MisconceptionName: Thinks cubing a number means adding 3 to that number

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b)
QuestionText:
In which region would \( x^{2}-10 x-25=0 \) belong? ![A Venn diagram made up of two overlapping circles. One is labelled 'Factorises' and the other is labelled 'Has one solution equal to 0'.
A is in the 'Factorises' circle only, B is in the overlap of the two circles, C is in the 'Has one solution equal to 0' circle only, and D is outside the circles.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes all quadratic equations have a solution of 0

answer: ![This pattern is made up of 12 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then 2 extra squares on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
ConstructName: Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern
QuestionText: What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns

ConstructName: For a given output find the input of a function machine
QuestionText: ![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "− 1" written inside it, the next rectangle has "✕ 2" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "8" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
MisconceptionName: Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine

ConstructName: Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)
QuestionText:
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-5 p
\)
MisconceptionName: When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise

ConstructName: Recognise an arithmetic sequence
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing arithmetic sequences.

Tom says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,8,11,14,17, \ldots \)

Katie says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,15,45,135,405, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount

ConstructName: Convert ratios to fractions
QuestionText: A lassi drink is made of yoghurt and water in the ratio \( 3: 1 \). What fraction of the drink is water?
MisconceptionName: When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total

ConstructName: Read values off a displacement-time graph
QuestionText:
How far away from home was Rachel at 12:15? ![A line graph with title "A graph to show the distance Rachel travels from her home on her daily run." 
The x-axis is titled "Time" and is labelled with times from 0800 to 1300 in steps of 1 hour, with the axis going half an hour beyond 1300.
The y-axis is titled "Distance from home (Km)" and the scale is from 0 to 8 in steps of 1km. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0800, 0), (0830, 2), (0900, 3.5),(1000, 6), (1030, 7), (1100, 7.5),(1230, 7.5),(1300, 4.5), (1330, 0).       
]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks there are 100m and a km

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations using balancing
QuestionText:
One of these equations has no real solutions.
Which is it?
MisconceptionName: Believes a number raised to a power will always give a positive answer

ConstructName: Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram
QuestionText:
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup. ![The image shows the cup with the 4 red balls and 3 yellow balls.]() Kate picks a yellow ball out and does not replace it.

She then has a second pick.
What is the probability the second pick is a red ball?
MisconceptionName: Does not reduce the denominator when an item is not replaced in a probability question

ConstructName: Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing parallel lines
Tom says \( y=2 x+5 \) and \( y=2 x-7 \) are parallel 
Katie says \( y=2 x+5 \) and \( y=3 x+5 \) are parallel
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient

ConstructName: Identify equivalent fractions when presented as shapes or objects
QuestionText: By comparing the fraction of the rectangle that is shaded in each diagram, decide which is the odd one out?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand equivalent fractions

ConstructName: Find a negative reciprocal
QuestionText: \( -\frac{3}{4} \times \star=-1 \) What should replace the star?
MisconceptionName: When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation

ConstructName: Calculate a string of multiplications mentally
QuestionText: \( 3 \times 5 \times 20= \)
MisconceptionName: Adds instead of multiples

ConstructName: Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator
QuestionText:
\(
1 \frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{3}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
MisconceptionName: When subtracting a fraction from a mixed number, assumes they subtract the numerator from the integer and the numerator of the mixed number

ConstructName: Identify parallel lines written in the form y = c - mx
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing parallel lines
Tom says \( y=4-3 x \) and \( y=4-2 x \) are parallel 
Katie says \( y=4-3 x \) and \( y=2-3 x \) are parallel
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient

ConstructName: Recognise the place value of each digit in integers
QuestionText:
What is the value of the \( 3 \) in the number below?
\(
43075
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not equate the value of a number with the place value column it is in

ConstructName: Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers
QuestionText: Kieran thinks of a number. He doubles it and adds \( 6 \). He then divides it by \( 2 \). The answer is \( 8 \). What was his original number? ![A cartoon of a man, in this question called Kieran, wearing a shirt, tie, grey trousers and black shoes. He is thinking of a number, we can tell this because he has a thought bubble above his head with a '?' in it.]()
MisconceptionName: When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation

ConstructName: Find 100 more than a given number
QuestionText: What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 72980 ? \)
MisconceptionName: Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'

ConstructName: Calculate the area of a rectangle where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: What is the area of this rectangle? ![A rectangle with a base length 5 cm and a perpendicular height of 8 cm.]()
MisconceptionName: Calculates perimeter when asked for area

ConstructName: Identify and count the faces, vertices and edges of a 3D shape
QuestionText: How many edges does this shape have? ![\( \Delta \)]()
MisconceptionName: Confuses the terms faces and edges

ConstructName: Calculate the square root of a number
QuestionText:
What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 13^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \ldots \ldots \ldots \) & \( 12^{2} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks the sum of 2 numbers, each squared first, is the same as adding the two numbers and then squaring the total

ConstructName: Multiply two decimals together with a different number of decimal places
MisconceptionName: When multiplying decimals, divides by the wrong power of 10 when reinserting the decimal

ConstructName: Carry out addition problems involving two negative integers
MisconceptionName: Believes adding two negatives gives a positive answer

ConstructName: Convert from mixed number fractions to improper fractions
QuestionText: Convert \( 3 \frac{1}{5} \) to an improper fraction.
MisconceptionName: Forgets to add the numerator when converting from a mixed number to an improper fraction

ConstructName: Find missing numbers in a fraction multiplication
MisconceptionName: Thinks if you multiply a fraction by itself you get a whole

ConstructName: Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols
QuestionText:
![Pictogram showing smiley faces, where each smiley face is worth 10 people. Game 1 has 5 smiley faces. Game 2 has 2 smiley faces. Game 3 has 3 smiley faces. Game 4 has 2 smiley faces.]() The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game?
MisconceptionName: Does not know you can find the mean from a pictogram

ConstructName: Change decimals of hours into minutes
QuestionText: \( 2.5 \) hours \( =_____ \) minutes
MisconceptionName: Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes

ConstructName: Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form
QuestionText: Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A quadratic curve with a minimum turning point at (-2, -1). The curve crosses the x axis at the points (-3,0) and (-1,0). It crosses the y axis at (0,3).]()
MisconceptionName: Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket

ConstructName: Convert fractions to ratios
QuestionText:
\( \frac{3}{7} \) of a group of students are boys.
What would be a possible ratio of boys to girls?
MisconceptionName: When converting fractions to ratios, puts the other side of the ratio as the total of the numerator and denominator

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c
QuestionText: Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+33 x+32 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b)
QuestionText:
This is the final stage of Beth's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?

\[
(h-8)(h+3)=0
\] \( h=\bigstar \) or \( h=-3 \)
MisconceptionName: Believes both solutions of a quadratic will have the same absolute value, even when the graph is not symmetrical about the y axis

ConstructName: Add algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other
QuestionText: Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{t}{s}+\frac{2 s}{t} \)
MisconceptionName: When adding/subtracting fractions, adds/subtracts the denominators and multiplies the numerators

answer:
![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "+ 3" written inside the next rectangle, "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3 + 2p" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has  "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(3 + p)" written inside it.]()
ConstructName: For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine
QuestionText: Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.

ConstructName: Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers
QuestionText:
Isaac is trying to solve the equation below.

Here are his steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct? ![An equation 15 =  2p - 4 on the first line. 
On the second line, Step 1 : 11 = 2p. 
On the third line, Step 2: 22 = p]()
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.

ConstructName: Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a common factor involving numeric and algebraic components (e.g. 5a)
QuestionText: When this expression is fully factorised, what is left inside the brackets? \( 24 a b c^{2}-16 b^{2} c \equiv 8 b c(\square) \)
MisconceptionName: Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket

ConstructName: Identify triangular numbers
QuestionText:
![\begin{tabular}{|lll|}
\hline\( \bullet \) & \( 8 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() How many circles will the next term in this sequence have?
MisconceptionName: Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern

answer: ![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "y" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "+ 1" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "✕ 5" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "𝑥"]()
ConstructName: Express a linear equation as a function machine
QuestionText:
Which function matches the equation
\[
y=5(x+1) ?
\]
MisconceptionName: When writing a function as a function machine confuses the input and the output.

ConstructName: Add fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators
QuestionText: \( 2 \frac{7}{10}+2 \frac{1}{4}= \) Leave your answer as a mixed number
MisconceptionName: When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators

ConstructName: Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)
QuestionText: Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square ABCE with various triangles attached to it.  The marked angle is between the lines CE and EG.]()
MisconceptionName: Gives 3-letter angle notation in the wrong order

ConstructName: Identify multiples of a number
QuestionText: If you list the multiples of \( 15 \) in ascending order, what is the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) number in the list?
MisconceptionName: Believes the first multiple of a is 2a

ConstructName: Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms
QuestionText:
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{5}{x} \times \frac{2 y}{x^{2}}
\)
MisconceptionName: Believes cubing a number means you multiply it by 3

ConstructName: Subtract two equations together to remove a variable
QuestionText:
Isaac is trying to solve the pair of simultaneous equations on the right.

\[
6 g+h=12
\]
\[
6 g-3 h=-3
\]

He decides to subtract the bottom equation from the top equation.
What will he end up with?
MisconceptionName: When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it

ConstructName: Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation
QuestionText: Without working out the exact answer, use estimation to decide which of the following answer is the most likely to be correct \( 505 \div 198 \)
MisconceptionName: Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)

ConstructName: Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension
QuestionText:
A shape is made up a square and regular pentagon.
The area of the square is \( 196 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \).

What is the perimeter of the compound shape? ![A regular pentagon with a square joined along one edge]()
MisconceptionName: Believes lines inside the shape are included when finding perimeter

ConstructName: Given the perimeter, work out a missing length requiring knowledge of the geometrical properties of the shape
QuestionText:
A regular octagon has a total perimeter of \( 12 \mathrm{~cm} \).
What is the length of each of its sides?
MisconceptionName: When given the perimeter of a regular polygon, multiplies instead of divides to find each side length

ConstructName: Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation
QuestionText:
Estimate the value of
\(
\frac{3.24 \times 17.6}{0.224}
\)
MisconceptionName: Rounds to the nearest integer when estimating

ConstructName: Recognise and name an expression
QuestionText: Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( 6-3 g \)
MisconceptionName: Confuses an equation with an expression

ConstructName: Identify or mark lines of symmetry on a shape
QuestionText: ![A rectangle divided into 3 equal horizontal sections. The middle section is white and the other 2 sections are blue. In the centre of the white section are five 5-pointed blue stars in the same formation as the 5 dots on a dice. All the stars are in exactly the same orientation, with one point pointing directly upwards.]() How many lines of symmetry does this shape have?
MisconceptionName: Ignores colours or design on shape when looking for symmetry

ConstructName: Tell the time from a 24 hour digital clock with times after half past the hour
QuestionText: Which clock shows ten to twelve at night?
MisconceptionName: Does not adjust the hour for “to” times

ConstructName: Interpret numbers in a frequency table
QuestionText:
Below is data from a Hockey team's matches over the course of a season, showing the number of goals scored. How many matches did the team play? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Goals scored & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
MisconceptionName: Believes the total frequency is the overall total in a grouped table

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx - c
QuestionText:
If
\(
m^{2}+5 m-14 \equiv(m+a)(m+b)
\)
then \( a \times b= \)
MisconceptionName: When factorising into double brackets, believes the product of the constants in the brackets is of the opposite sign to the constant in the expanded equation.

ConstructName: Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio
QuestionText: ![A group of 8 squares and 5 circles]() What is the ratio of squares to circles?
MisconceptionName: When writing ratio from diagram, writes total as one side

ConstructName: Find missing numbers in a fraction multiplication
QuestionText:
Barry has two fraction cards.
\( \frac{3}{7} \quad \square\)
The product of the cards is \( \frac{2}{5} \) What is the other card?
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to interpret a fraction worded problem

ConstructName: Work out the equation of a line with a negative gradient from an accurate drawing
QuestionText: If you were to write the equation of this line in the form \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{m} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{c} \), what is the value of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) ? ![Graph showing straight line with y intercept (0,0) and x intercept (0,0). Also goes through the point (6,-4)]()
MisconceptionName: Believes gradient = change in x/change in y

ConstructName: Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension
QuestionText: A square has an area \( 36 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \) What is the length of one side of the square?
MisconceptionName: Confuses square rooting and halving the number

ConstructName: Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator
QuestionText: Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{t^{2}+t-2}{t-1} \)
MisconceptionName: Incorrectly factorises a quadratic

ConstructName: Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons
QuestionText: An equilateral shape must have...
MisconceptionName: Does know know equilateral means the same as regular

ConstructName: Identify vertical translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions
QuestionText:
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=f(x)\)
to the graph of
\(y=f(x)+1\)
MisconceptionName: Believes f(x) + a translates the function right a units

ConstructName: Given an exchange rate x = ny, convert to work out the number of x’s for a given y
QuestionText:
\begin{tabular}{|l|}
\hline Exchange rates \\
\\
\( £ 1=€ 1.17 \) \\
\( £ 1=\$ 1.31 \)
\end{tabular} How much is \( \$ 5 \) worth in pounds ( \( £ \) )?
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to calculate with exchange rates

ConstructName: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed
QuestionText:
Rearrange the following equation to make \( r \) the subject
\[
p=3 r-5
\]
MisconceptionName: Confuses the inverse operations of addition and subtraction when rearranging equations

ConstructName: Raise an integer to a positive non-unit fraction power
MisconceptionName: Assumes they multiply by the numerator of fractional index

ConstructName: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing rearranging \( p=\sqrt{5-q} \) to make \( q \) the subject Tom says a correct first line of working could be: \( p^{2}=5-q \) Katie says a correct first line of working could be: \( p+\sqrt{q}=\sqrt{5} \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression

ConstructName: Multiply an integer and an algebraic term
QuestionText:
James is expanding these two brackets.

What should he get when he multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (x-8)(x-2). The arrows are pointing at the x in the first bracket and the -2 in the second bracket.]()
MisconceptionName: Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket

ConstructName: Find missing angles on parallel lines using corresponding angles
QuestionText: Calculate the missing angle: ![Two vertical lines marked with arrows are crossed by one diagonal line. Two angles are marked; they are both on the upper side of the diagonal line and to the right of the vertical lines. One is marked '70', the other '?'. ]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks corresponding angles sum to 360 degrees

ConstructName: Use the prime factor decomposition of a number to calculate the number
QuestionText: What number should replace \(\color{gold}\bigstar \) in the Venn diagram? ![A Venn diagram with two circles. The left hand one is labelled 'prime factors of \star\', the right hand circle is labelled 'prime factors of 60'. In the left hand circle, there is an 11, in the overlap there is a 2 and a 3, and in the right hand circle there is a 2 and a heart. ]()
MisconceptionName: Believes factors add to give a number

ConstructName: Round integers to the nearest other integer value (e.g. 20, 50 etc)
QuestionText: What is \( 623 \) rounded to the nearest \( 50 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)

answer: ![Net showing two squares and four rectangles]()
ConstructName: Identify the net of a non-prism
QuestionText: Which diagram is the net for a square based pyramid?
MisconceptionName: Struggles to visualise nets of 3D shapes

ConstructName: Round numbers to one decimal place
QuestionText:
\[
34590.8549
\]
What is this number rounded to \( 1 \) decimal place?
MisconceptionName: Changes wrong place value column when rounding

ConstructName: Identify rational and irrational numbers
QuestionText:
Which of these two numbers are rational?
\(
\pi \text { and } \frac{1}{\pi}
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not know the definition of a rational number

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c
QuestionText:
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+2 p+3
\)
MisconceptionName: Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x

ConstructName: Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c
QuestionText:
When Aaron completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\(
3 g^{2}-18 g-7 \equiv 3(g-3)^{2} \triangle
\)
MisconceptionName: Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling

ConstructName: Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of one expression
QuestionText:
What is a correct solution for the following pair of simultaneous equations:
\[4x+y=7\]
\[3x+2y=4\]
MisconceptionName: When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation

ConstructName: Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division
QuestionText:
Problem P: \( 6 \div 3+5= \)
Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \times 5= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
MisconceptionName: Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)

ConstructName: Change decimals of hours into minutes
MisconceptionName: Thinks there are 10 minutes in an hour

ConstructName: Identify mathematical instruments and their functions
QuestionText: What is the name of the mathematical instrument used to construct circles?
MisconceptionName: Does not know the word and/or does not know the function of a compass

ConstructName: Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: Which calculation would give you the area of the face of this cuboid labelled \( Q \) ('the top')? ![A cuboid with dimensions 6cm by 3cm by 4 cm. The top face Q is marked. It is a rectangle with dimensions 6cm by 3cm.]()
MisconceptionName: Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face

ConstructName: Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°
QuestionText: What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The outer scale goes from 0 to 360, clockwise. The angle is a reflex angle that is between the red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale) on the protractor and goes clockwise round to the red line that is half way between 200 and 210 (outer scale) and halfway between 340 and 330 (inner scale).]()
MisconceptionName: Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (-2,3) (-2,6) and (0,5). The point P is the coordinate (0,5)]()

Calculate

\frac{1}{6} \div 3
\)

\hline Black & \( 2 \) \\
\hline Silver & \( 4 \) \\
\hline Red & \( 1 \) \\
\hline Other & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
MisconceptionName: Believes you do not include an "other" category when finding a total frequency

Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Monday and the upper one showing Tuesdays sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Teas bar lower section is 1 tick below 50 on the vertical scale, and the whole bar's height is 2 ticks above 100 on the vertical scale.
]()
MisconceptionName: When reading a composite bar chart, just reads total height of bar

QuestionText: Use the graph to approximate the solution to \( x^{2}<5 \) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2 drawn on.]()

Pattern 1 is a rectangle with a total of 6 circles surrounding it. Pattern 2 is 2 rectangles with a total of 10 circles surrounding it. Pattern 3 is 3 rectangles with a total of 14 circles surrounding it.]()

 \( \frac{1}{3} \) of \( \mathrm{A} \) is \( 12 \)

 ![\( A \)]()

(d+3)^{2}=25
\)

answer: A triangle with three sides of equal length and three equal angles.

QuestionText: Calculate \( t \). ![Two parallel horizontal lines with a transversal. The lower interior angle to the right of the transversal is marked 't'. The angle to the right of the transversal and lying above the upper parallel line is marked '78'. ]()
