MisconceptionName: Does not know the properties of a rectangle

ConstructName: Rearrange a quadratic equation so that it is in the correct form to be factorised
QuestionText:
What would be the most useful first step if we wanted to solve the following quadratic equation?

\(
x^{2}-5 x=6
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to be factorised

ConstructName: Divide integers by 1000
MisconceptionName: Divided by 100 rather than 1000

ConstructName: Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving non-linear variables
QuestionText:
\(
x(2 x-1)+3(4 x-2) \equiv P x^{2}+Q x+R
\)

What is the value of \( R \) ?
MisconceptionName: Believes you can add or subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation

ConstructName: Identify the net of a prism
QuestionText: Name the polyhedron that can be made from this net ![Net showing four rectangles and two squares]()
MisconceptionName: Confuses pyramid with prism

ConstructName: Work out the equation of a line when given a positive gradient and a point on the line
QuestionText: A line has a gradient of \( 4 \) and passes through the point \( (1,9) \). What is it's equation?
MisconceptionName: Believes  c, in y=mx+c, will be the y value of the coordinate given despite the x coordinate not being 0.

ConstructName: Recognise cube numbers
QuestionText:
\[
27,64,125, \ldots
\]

This is the \( 3^{\text {rd }}, 4^{\text {th }} \) and \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term from what sequence of numbers?
MisconceptionName: Thinks cube numbers are triangular numbers

ConstructName: Recognise and name a term
QuestionText: Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe \( y^{2} \) in this: \( y^{2}-9 \)
MisconceptionName: Confuses a term with a variable

ConstructName: Identify co-interior angles
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about angle relationships on parallel lines.
Tom says allied (co-interior) angles are equal.
Katie says corresponding angles are equal.
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Thinks co-interior angles are equal

ConstructName: Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers
MisconceptionName: Multiplies by the index

ConstructName: Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape
QuestionText: Which shape has the highest order of rotational symmetry?
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² + bx + c where a is prime
QuestionText:
Step 1: Factorise the following expression
\(
2 x^{2}+7 x+3
\)
MisconceptionName: When factorising a quadratic with a non-unit coefficient of x squared, believes that coefficient will be in front of both x terms in the factorised form

ConstructName: Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c
QuestionText:
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[y=x^{2}-x\] \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -7 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
MisconceptionName: Believes the square of a negative will also be negative

ConstructName: Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers
QuestionText:
What answer would your calculator give if you typed in
\(
-6^{2}
\) ![A scientific calculator]()
MisconceptionName: Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order

ConstructName: Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units
QuestionText: What is value of \( p \) in this compound shape made with rectangles? ![Compound shape made of two rectangles with the sides labelled p cm, 10 cm, 7 cm, 3 cm and 4 cm. One side is unlabelled.]()
MisconceptionName: Makes an assumption about line segments being equal within a shape

ConstructName: Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures
QuestionText:
\( 0.009753 \)

What is this number rounded to \( 2 \) significant figures?
MisconceptionName: Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)

ConstructName: Rotate an object or point 180° about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object
QuestionText:
![A pair of axes: x-axis is from -3 to 4; y-axis is from -4 to 4. A quadrilateral, labelled "P", is made by joining the following points, in order, with straight lines: (-3, 1), (-1, 1), (-1, 3), (-3, 4) and back to (-3, 1). The point (-1, 3) is marked with a red dot.
Also, the following points are plotted and labelled with the following letters: A (3, 1); B (1, -1); C (3, -1); D (1, -3).]() Shape \( \mathrm{P} \) is rotated \( 180^{\circ} \) through the origin.

Where will the red point be on the rotated shape?
MisconceptionName: Reflects instead of rotates

ConstructName: Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places
MisconceptionName: Multiplies rather than divides

ConstructName: Write a formula to describe a situation
QuestionText: A taxi driver charges an initial \( £ 2.50 \) plus \( £ 1.20 \) per mile travelled. Which of the following expressions is correct for the total cost, \( T \), of a journey of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) miles?
MisconceptionName: Has made an order of operations mistake when writing a formula from a given situation

ConstructName: Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: What is the area of this shape? ![Right angled triangle on square grid with area of 3 square units]()
MisconceptionName: Does not realise that the area of a triangle is half the area of the contatining rectangle

ConstructName: Round integers to the nearest 1000
QuestionText: What is \( 637 \) rounded to the nearest \( 1000 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Rounds down instead of up

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form x(x + b)
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to solve this equation: 

\(
x^{2}+4 x=0
\)

Tom says one solution is \( x=2 \)

Katie says one solution is \( x=0 \)

Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Thinks x^2 - a^2x is a valid form of difference of two squares

ConstructName: Identify a unit of volume or capacity
QuestionText:
James has answered a question on volume. His answer is 8.5.
Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

\(
8.5 \,\bigstar
\)

Which of the following units is definitely wrong?
MisconceptionName: Does not know that units of volume are usually cubed

ConstructName: Draw the net of a prism
QuestionText:
This is an incomplete net for a triangular prism.

What shapes do you add to complete this net? ![An incomplete net of a triangular prism comprising a rectangle (landscape) and an equilateral triangle. These 2 shapes are attached to each other along one side (the righthand shorter side of the rectangle, which is the same length as the sides of the triangle). ]()
MisconceptionName: Confuses pyramid with prism

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b)
QuestionText:
The area of the trapezium on the right is \( 12 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled x -1 and x + 3 and the perpendicular height as x.]() Based on the information given, Adam writes this formula:
\(x^{2}+x=12\)

What are the two solutions to this equation?
MisconceptionName: Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the constants in the factorised form

ConstructName: Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram
QuestionText: What is the equation of this line? ![A set of axes with a line drawn on. The lines passes through the points: (0,2) (1,2) (2,2) (3,2) and (4,2)]()
MisconceptionName: Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line

ConstructName: Identify a radius
QuestionText: What is the correct name for the line marked on the circle? ![A circle with a line from the centre of the circle to the circumference.]()
MisconceptionName: Confuses tangent and radius

ConstructName: Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape that makes a backwards "L" shape from 2 rectangles.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 11cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 12cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 5cm. The vertical height of the bottom rectangle is labelled 4cm. The top rectangle is shaded.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape

ConstructName: Identify unit fractions when part of a shape
QuestionText: What should replace the question mark? ![A bar split into 5 equal parts. Four parts are shaded pink. The total length of the shaded parts is labelled 4/5. One shaded part is labelled with a question mark.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not understand what each part of a bar model represents as a fraction

ConstructName: Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units
QuestionText: Sally wants to calculate the area of this trapezium using the formula: Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![A trapezium with the parallel sides labelled 6cm and 2cm, the slant height labelled 7cm and the perpendicular height labelled 5cm.]() What is the values of \( h \) ?
MisconceptionName: Uses slant height instead of perpendicular height to find area of a trapezium

ConstructName: For a given output find the input of a function machine
QuestionText: \( input\Rightarrow(+1) \Rightarrow(\times2) \Rightarrow9\) What is the input of this function machine?
MisconceptionName: Reverses the order of operations but does not apply the inverse operations when finding the input of a function machine

ConstructName: Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c
QuestionText: In which region would \( x-y=2 \) belong? ![A Venn diagram with two overlapping sets. The set on the left is 'Crosses the y-axis at (0,-2)' and the set on the right is 'Has a positive gradient'. A is in only 'Crosses the y-axis at (0,-2)' set, B is in the intersection, C is in only  'Has a positive gradient' set and D is outside both sets.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes the constant gives the y-intercept even when a line is not written in the form y = mx + c

ConstructName: Divide a decimal by an integer
QuestionText:
What is the mean of the following numbers?
\( 1, \quad 0.1, \quad 0.01 \)
MisconceptionName: Finds the median instead of the mean

ConstructName: Recognise and name a variable
QuestionText: Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe \( t \) in this: \( 9-3 t \)
MisconceptionName: Confuses a variable with an equation

ConstructName: Solve problems that combine addition or subtraction with multiplication
QuestionText:
Sara has \( £ 2.79 \).
Rhys has \( 3 \) times as much as Sara.
How much do they have altogether?
Which calculation would not find the answer?
MisconceptionName: Does not think that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers is valid.

ConstructName: Divide proper fractions in the form: Integer ÷ Fraction
QuestionText:
\( \frac{4}{9} \) of a litre of paint can cover \( 1 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \).
What area can \( 4 \) litres of paint cover?
MisconceptionName: Multiplies up without finding unit price in proportion question

ConstructName: Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression
QuestionText:
Expand:
\[
6(p-2)
\]
MisconceptionName: Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket

ConstructName: Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are arguing about the solution to this inequality:
\(t+3>-0.3\)

Jo says \( t \) could be \( -3.4 \)

Paul says \( t \) could be \( 3.4 \)

Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater

ConstructName: Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the shorter one
QuestionText:
These two shapes are similar.

What is the value of \( y \) ? ![The diagram is of two trapeziums. The base of each trapezium is parallel with its top side.
The smaller trapezium has base 60cm and top labelled y.
The larger trapezium has base 150cm and top 70cm.]()
MisconceptionName: Estimated when not appropriate

ConstructName: Use perimeter to write algebraic expressions
QuestionText: What is an expression for the perimeter of this rectangle? ![Yellow rectangle with base length 5a and side length a]()
MisconceptionName: When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths

ConstructName: Describe a reflection in a vertical line by giving the line of reflection as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText: Which is the correct description of the transformation that maps shape A onto shape \( B \) ? ![A coordinate grid with two triangles drawn on it. Triangle A has the coordinates: (6,4) (4,4) and (4,5). Triangle B has the coordinates: (-4,4) (-2,4) and (-2,5).]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks y = ? is a vertical line through ?

ConstructName: Recognise and use the law of distributivity
QuestionText:
What word do we use to describe the relationship:
\(
7 \times 9=5 \times 9+2 \times 9
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise the distributive property

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c
QuestionText: When \( x^{2}+9 x+14 \) is factorised, what will appear in the box below? ![Bracket (x+2) and a rectangular box beside it where the second bracket should be.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer

ConstructName: Divide a decimal by an integer
MisconceptionName: Multiplies rather than divides

ConstructName: Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence
QuestionText: Here are the first three terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llll}98 & 92 & 86 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the nth term of this sequence.
MisconceptionName: Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion

ConstructName: Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring no scaling of expressions
MisconceptionName: Believes 0 is not a real solution to an equation

ConstructName: Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction
MisconceptionName: When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and multiplies the denominators

ConstructName: Substitute positive non-integer values into expressions involving powers or roots
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are discussing quadratic equations.

Jo says there is no value of \( x \) that can make \( (1-x)^{2} \) negative.

Paul says there is no value of \( x \) that can make \( 1-x^{2} \) positive.
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Assumes a fact without considering enough examples

ConstructName: Interpret continuous data using a line graph
QuestionText: ![Graph titled height of rocket with Height in metres versus time in seconds]() How many metres did the rocket travel between \( 10 \) and \( 40 \) seconds?
MisconceptionName: When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points.

ConstructName: Recognise cube numbers
QuestionText: Which of these is a cube number?
MisconceptionName: Mixes up square numbers and cube numbers

ConstructName: Convert fractions to percentages containing 1 decimal place
QuestionText:
Convert this fraction to a percentage
\(
\frac{27}{200}
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not understand a percentage is out of 100

ConstructName: Round numbers greater than 1 to three or more significant figures
QuestionText: What is \( \mathbf{2 . 5 0 6 7 1 0} \) rounded to three significant figures?
MisconceptionName: Rounds down instead of up

ConstructName: Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle
QuestionText: An isosceles triangle must have ...
MisconceptionName: Does not know the meaning of the word parallel

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 7, y-axis from -2 to 8. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 4), (4, 4), (2, 7). Point (2, 4) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=4 is shown with a blue dashed line.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected

ConstructName: Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where at least one value is negative and at least one is a non-integer
QuestionText:
Here are two points and their midpoint.
What should replace the triangle? ![The image is a set of axes with three points marked. One point is (1,7). The midpoint is (-1, 0.5). The third point is given as (star, triangle), so the triangle is the y value of the point.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes midpoint calculation is just half of the difference

ConstructName: Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication
QuestionText:
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Fred is monitoring the growth of his plant. The plant grew \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) every week for \( 35 \) weeks.
By how much did the plant grow in total?
MisconceptionName: Adds rather than multiplies when asked for a total

ConstructName: Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram
QuestionText:
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 4 red and 3 yellow balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Kate picks out three balls at the same time.

She wants to work out the probability all the balls are red.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise that choosing 2 items at once means the first item does not get replaced in a probability question

ConstructName: For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine
QuestionText: Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.

ConstructName: Identify common multiples of three or more numbers
QuestionText: Which of the following numbers is a common multiple of \( 4,6 \) and \( 12 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Identifies a common multiple of two numbers when asked to consider a common multiple of three numbers

ConstructName: Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers
QuestionText: \( \fbox{-5} \) x\( \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{4} = \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{-12} - \hspace{0.2cm}\fbox{ ? } \)
MisconceptionName: Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer

ConstructName: Multiplication, division and power law of indices with positive integer powers
QuestionText:
\(\frac{\left(5^{6}\right)^{4}}{5^{2}} \equiv 5^{n}\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
MisconceptionName: Believes when dividing numbers with the same base you divide the powers, rather than subtracting

ConstructName: Form expressions from situations described in words
QuestionText: Which of these always produces consecutive numbers if \( n \) is a positive integer?
MisconceptionName: Does not know the meaning of consecutive

ConstructName: Multiply two decimals together with a different number of decimal places
MisconceptionName: Does not understand place value within a number

answer: To get the next term you square the previous term and add \( 1 \)
ConstructName: Describe a term-to-term sequence
QuestionText:
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
2, \quad 5, \quad 14, \quad 41 \ldots
\]
MisconceptionName: Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule

ConstructName: Write 3 digit numbers as words
QuestionText:
How do you write this number in words?
\( 107 \)
MisconceptionName: The student does not understand the place value of 3-digit numbers

ConstructName: Expand products of three binomials in the form (x + a)(x + b)(x + c)
QuestionText:
When Nadia expands these brackets, how many terms should she get after she simplifies?
\(
(p+8)(p+2)(p+1)
\)
MisconceptionName: Believes a cubic expression should have three terms

ConstructName: Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data
QuestionText:
Without using a calculator, what is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
3,4,3,4,4
\]
MisconceptionName: When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the mode

ConstructName: Add proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor
QuestionText:
\(
\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{10}=\frac{\bigstar}{30}
\)
What should replace the star?
MisconceptionName: Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions

ConstructName: Calculate the mode as an average from a list of data when there are two or more modes
QuestionText:
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\[
1,1,4,6,7,7
\]
MisconceptionName: When there are two modes, finds the mean of these values and gives that as the mode

ConstructName: Calculate the square of a number
QuestionText: Which is the best estimate for \( (4.2)^{2} \) ?
MisconceptionName: Multiplies by the index

ConstructName: Find missing angles using angles on a straight line
QuestionText: ![Two angles meeting on a straight line labelled n and 48 degrees, one angle further down the straight line labelled 30 degrees]() What is the size of angle \( n \) ?
MisconceptionName: Thinks that all angles anywhere along a straight line add to 180

answer: To get the next term you square the previous term and add \( 5 \)
ConstructName: Describe a term-to-term sequence
QuestionText: Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence? \( 2, \quad 9, \quad 11, \quad 20, \quad \ldots \)
MisconceptionName: Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule

ConstructName: Given the name of a polygon, draw or identify a corresponding diagram
QuestionText: Which of the following shapes is a hexagon?
MisconceptionName: Confuses octagon and hexagon

ConstructName: Use angles around a point to form and solve algebraic equations
QuestionText: Which of the following equations is true based on the diagram? ![Angles around a point made up of two angles labelled: f and f-20]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks index notation represents repeated addition rather than repeated multiplication

ConstructName: Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension
QuestionText:
A square has an area of \( 100 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)
What is the length of each side of the square?
MisconceptionName: Confuses square rooting and halving the number

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
A point, \( Q \), has coordinates \( (4,-4) \)

The point is reflected in the line \( y=-x \)

What are the new coordinates of point Q?
MisconceptionName: Believes reflection in y = -x switches x and y coordinates

ConstructName: Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division
MisconceptionName: Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order

ConstructName: Represent positive unit fractions on a number line
QuestionText:
The probability of picking a green ball is \( \frac{1}{5} \)
Where is this value on the probability scale? ![A diagram showing a probability scale with 10 segments. The scale starts at 0.0, has 0.5 marked after 5 segments, and 1.0 marked at the end, after 10 segments. A is marked after 2 segments, B after 4, C after 5 and D after 7.]()
MisconceptionName: Converts a fraction to a decimal by using the denominator after the decimal point

ConstructName: Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
38.8745 \div 7.9302
\]

Tom says \( 40 \div 7.9302 \) would give an overestimate.

Katie says \( 38.8745 \div 8 \) would give an overestimate.

Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes that the larger the divisor, the larger the answer.

ConstructName: Identify triangular numbers
QuestionText: \( 1,3,6,10,15,21,28 \ldots \) What is the name commonly given to this sequence of numbers?
MisconceptionName: Believes square numbers are triangle numbers

ConstructName: Manipulate both equations so that they are in a form to be added or subtracted
QuestionText:
Sandeep wants to eliminate \( l \) from these simultaneous equations.
\(\begin{array}{l}
2 l+3 m=13 \\
3 l+4 m=17
\end{array}\)

First he will transform both of them to get them in an appropriate form.
Which of the following is a correct transformation?
MisconceptionName: When solving simultaneous equations, thinks you only transform the term that is being eliminated, rather than the whole equation.

ConstructName: Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method
MisconceptionName: When multiplying involving a multiple of 10, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be

ConstructName: Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number
QuestionText:
Simplify (if possible):
\(
6^{9} \div 6^{3}
\)
MisconceptionName: When dividing numbers with the same base divides the base numbers and the powers

ConstructName: Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about rounding.

Tom says \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3 4 5 6} \) rounded to \( 2 \) significant figures is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3} \)

Katie says \( 0.03456 \) rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3} \)

Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)

ConstructName: Round non-integers to other non-integer values (e.g. 0.02)
QuestionText: What is \( \mathbf{1 . 5 1 6} \) rounded to the nearest \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \) ?
MisconceptionName: Rounds up instead of down

ConstructName: Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms
MisconceptionName: Does not understand how to subtract algebraic fractions

answer: ![Circle with a line below it, touching the circle in one place]()
ConstructName: Identify the circumference
QuestionText: Which of the following diagrams shows the circumference of a circle?
MisconceptionName: Confuses tangent and circumference

ConstructName: Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers
QuestionText: Which of the following fractions is equivalent to \( \frac{9}{12} \) ?
MisconceptionName: Believes equivalent fractions are formed with addition not multiplication

answer: Miran is correct because subtraction is not commutative
ConstructName: Understand the non-commutativity of subtraction
QuestionText:
Miran says the following:

“It doesn't matter if you do \( 81-53 \) or \( 53-81 \), you get the same answer."

What do you think?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative

ConstructName: Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a numberline
QuestionText: Which inequality is represented by the diagram? ![A number line with a hollow circle above -1with an arrow coming out of it over the numbers -2, -3, -4, -5 etc]()
MisconceptionName: Mixes up greater than and less than symbols

ConstructName: Find the volume scale factor of similar shapes given the length scale factor
QuestionText:
![Two cuboids. Cuboid P has width 5cm, and cuboid Q has width 15cm.]() Shape P and Shape Q are similar.

What is the volume scale factor to get from Shape \( P \) to Shape \( Q \) ?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that the volume of an enlarged shape is the volume of the original multiplied by the cube of the scale factor of the lengths.

ConstructName: Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern
QuestionText: How many squares will the next term in this sequence have? ![A diagram showing the first 3 patterns in a sequences. Pattern 1 contains 7 squares, pattern 2 contains 5 squares and pattern 3 contains 3 squares.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns

ConstructName: Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10
MisconceptionName: Does not understand a percentage can be applied to something not out of 100

ConstructName: Identify percentages of a shape where the percent is a multiple of 10
QuestionText: What percentage of this shape is shaded? ![A bar split into 5 equal parts. 3 parts are shaded.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not understand a percentage is out of 100

ConstructName: Recognise perpendicular lines
QuestionText: ![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. AB is a vertical line measuring 4 units. CD is a diagonal line, with a positive gradient of 1.5. EF is a vertical line measuring 3 units. GH is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -4/6. IJ is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -3. KL is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 1/3. MN is a vertical line measuring 6 units. OP is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 6/4.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to IJ?
MisconceptionName: Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and vertical

ConstructName: Substitute numbers into a SUVAT equation to work out distance
QuestionText:
\( s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \) What is the value of \( S \) when
\[\begin{array}{l} a=4 \\ u=3 \\ t=5\end{array}\]
MisconceptionName: When a variable in an expression has a power, thinks the power applies to the whole expression

ConstructName: Substitute negative integer values into formulae involving powers or roots
QuestionText:
\(
T=k^{4}
\)

What is the value of \( T \) when \( k=-3 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c
QuestionText: Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( x^{2}-9 \)
MisconceptionName: Confuses the factorised form of repeated roots and the difference of 2 squares

ConstructName: Add algebraic fractions with the same denominator
QuestionText:
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible
\(
\frac{2}{x}+\frac{3}{x}
\)
MisconceptionName: When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators

ConstructName: Find the reciprocal of an integer
QuestionText: What is the reciprocal of \( 7 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Makes the number negative when asked to find the reciprocal

ConstructName: Identify the line of symmetry of curves in the form (x + a)(x + b)
QuestionText: This is the graph of \( y=(x+4)(x-2) \) ![\( W \)]() What is the equation of the line of symmetry?
MisconceptionName: Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines

ConstructName: Answer fraction problems that require the use of BIDMAS
MisconceptionName: When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form x(x + b)
QuestionText:
Solve this equation, giving all solutions:
\(
k^{2}-8 k=0
\)
MisconceptionName: Believes they can divide by a variable without checking whether it could equal zero

ConstructName: Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group
QuestionText:
The pie chart shows the favourite subjects of children at a school.

If \( 18 \) students chose Science, how many chose French? ![A pie chart split into four parts, labelled with school subjects. The part for Mathematics is 144 degrees, Science is 36 degrees, English is 72 degrees and French is 108 degrees.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes the angle in a pie chart sector is equal to the frequency

ConstructName: Identify the net of a prism
QuestionText: This is the net of a... ![An image of six connected rectangles. The six rectangles are 3 lots of identical rectangle pairs. There is a central rectangle with identical rectangles attached to the left and right of it. It then has identical rectangles attached to its top and bottom sides. Below the rectangle attached to the bottom side is another attached rectangle which is identical to the central rectangle.]()
MisconceptionName: Mixes up cubes and cuboids

ConstructName: Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about parallel lines. 
Tom says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{7} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3 x + 7} \) are parallel. 
Katie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{7} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{2 2} \) are parallel. 
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient

ConstructName: Multiply a decimal by an integer
MisconceptionName: When multiplying decimals, divides by the wrong power of 10 when reinserting the decimal

answer: ![A curved graph that starts in the top left, travels steeply down and right, turns to travel steeply up and right, to the origin, where it turns around to travel down and right again.]()
ConstructName: Recognise a reciprocal graph from its shape
QuestionText: Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a reciprocal function?
MisconceptionName: confuses cubic and reciprocal graphs

ConstructName: Recognise the angles around a point relationship
QuestionText: What is the relationship between these two angles? ![\( \theta \)]()
MisconceptionName: Believes angles around a point sum to 180

ConstructName: Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention
QuestionText:
\( a, b \) and \( c \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{a+b}{c}=(a+b) \div c
\)
Is the above relationship...
MisconceptionName: Does not realize we can write a division as a fraction

answer: "Add three to a and then multiply by b."
ConstructName: Describe the meaning algebraic terms with no powers
QuestionText:
Which statement correctly describes the following algebraic expression?
\(
3+a b
\)
MisconceptionName: Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order

ConstructName: Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension
QuestionText: The area of this trapezium is \( 45 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). What would the perpendicular height, \( h \), of the trapezium be? ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled as 10cm and 5cm and the perpendicular height labelled with h]()
MisconceptionName: Uses only the base and perpendicular height when calculating the area of a trapezium

ConstructName: Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 3 or more decimal places
QuestionText: Convert \( \frac{97}{250} \) into a decimal
MisconceptionName: Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator

ConstructName: Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons.
Tom says if all the angles are Katie says if all the sides are equal equal then the polygon must be length then the polygon must be regular regular
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that all angles and sides must be equal for regular shapes

ConstructName: Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape
QuestionText: What mixed number fraction is represented below? ![Four bars, each split into six equal parts. In three of the shapes, all six parts are shaded. In the fourth shape, five out of six parts are shaded.]()
MisconceptionName: Confused mixed numbers with improper fractions

answer: ![11 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 6 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
ConstructName: Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one
QuestionText: What is the 7th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is 1 orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 2 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
MisconceptionName: When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives a different term, which is not the next

ConstructName: Find another power of 10 more than a given number

Convert this into an improper fraction:

4 \frac{2}{3}
\)
MisconceptionName: Thinks you multiply by the numerator and add the denominator when converting a mixed number to an improper fraction

ConstructName: Identify a unit of length

George has answered a question on perimeter and worked out an answer of \( 310 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 310 \color{yellow} \bigstar\)
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise feet (ft) as a unit of length

ConstructName: Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers
QuestionText:
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 7 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
MisconceptionName: Thinks the inverse of addition is division

ConstructName: Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form
QuestionText: Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A graph of a quadratic curve that crosses the x axis at (1,0) and (3,0) and crosses the y axis at (0,3).]()
MisconceptionName: Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket

ConstructName: Complete missing number mental subtraction problems with numbers over 1000

A \( 4 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true

\square -7806=1253
\)
What is the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
MisconceptionName: does not know the meaning of the word digit

ConstructName: Carry out addition problems involving two negative integers
MisconceptionName: Believes adding two negatives gives a positive answer

ConstructName: Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule

MisconceptionName: Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount

\]

ConstructName: Complete mental addition problems up to 1000
MisconceptionName: When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit

ConstructName: Factorise a single bracket containing a linear expression by taking out a single numeric common factor (e.g. 6)

MisconceptionName: Believes factors add to give a number

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
The triangle is reflected in the \( x \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 8, y-axis from -5 to 6. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 0), (4, 0), (2, 3). Point (2, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
MisconceptionName: Believes that reflection always switches the x and y coordinates

QuestionText: What is the equation of this line? ![A graph showing a horizontal line going through 4 on the y axis.]()
MisconceptionName: Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line

answer: ![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise , to the red line that is half way between 40 and 50 (inner scale) and halfway between 140 and 130 (outer scale).]()
ConstructName: Use a protractor to measure angles between 90° and 180°
QuestionText: Which diagram shows an angle of \( 135^{\circ} \) ?
MisconceptionName: Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles

answer: The mass of sand in the bucket
ConstructName: Interpret linear sections of real life graphs
QuestionText:
The graph on the right shows the mass of sand in a bucket over time

The gradient of the positive sloping section would tell us... ![A graph with time (secs) on the horizontal axis and mass (g) on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels in a straight line up and right, travels horizontally, then travels in a straight line down and right back to the x-axis, more steeply than the start. ]()
MisconceptionName: Does not realise that gradient represents rate of change

ConstructName: Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape
QuestionText: ![A solid yellow equilateral triangle (3 sided polygon with all 3 sides of equal length).]() What is the order of rotational symmetry of this equilateral triangle?
MisconceptionName: Gives one fewer order of rotational symmetry than there is

ConstructName: Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs

\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\

\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?

\hline \( 5 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()

The fifth term is made from two green dots and three red dots. The sixth term is made of five red dots and three green dots. ]()

answer:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle

answer:

ConstructName: Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one

Tom and Katie are discussing this sequence. ![3 consecutive patterns of a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a green triangle inside a square shape that is made from 4 separate red sticks. The second term is Pattern 1 but with 1 more green triangle and 3 more red sticks so that the 2 triangles are enclosed by squares made from red sticks. The third term is Pattern 2 but with 1 more green triangle and 3 more red sticks so that the 3 triangles are enclosed by squares made from red sticks.]() Tom says the number of triangles in the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of triangles in the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term.

Katie says the number of sticks in the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term will be

ConstructName: Order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number
QuestionText: Which diagram represents the largest fraction?
MisconceptionName: Thinks a greater number of shaded parts represents a greater fraction

ConstructName: Multiplication law of indices with positive integer powers and a different base number
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about \( 4^{2} \times 2^{2} \)
Tom says \( 4^{2} \times 2^{2}=64 \)
Katie says \( 4^{2} \times 2^{2}=8^{4} \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: When multiplying numbers with different bases, multiplies the powers and multiplies the base numbers.

ConstructName: Substitute into simple formulae given in words
QuestionText:
A quick way to change approximately from miles to kilometers is to divide the number of miles by \( 3 \) and then multiply by \( 5 \).
Using this method, how many kilometres are equal to \( 15 \) miles?
MisconceptionName: Subtracts instead of divides

ConstructName: Order numbers in standard form that are between 0 and 1
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing standard form.

Tom says \( 9.3 \times 10^{5}>2.3 \times 10^{6} \)

Katie says \( 9.3 \times 10^{-5}>2.3 \times 10^{-6} \)

Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: When ordering numbers in standard form just looks at the decimal without multiplying by a power of 10

ConstructName: Find missing angles in an isosceles triangle
QuestionText:
This is an isosceles triangle.
Calculate the size of angle \( p \). ![An isosceles triangle with one angle labelled 56 degrees and one angle labelled p [not to scale]]()
MisconceptionName: Forgets to subtract sum of angles we know from 180 to find missing angle in a triangle

ConstructName: Understand the non-commutativity of division
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie want to share £2 between \( 4 \) people.
Tom says you would calculate the amount each person gets by doing \( 4 \div 2 \)
Katie says you would calculate the amount each person gets by doing \( 2 \div 4 \)
Who do you agree with?
MisconceptionName: Believes division is commutative

ConstructName: Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units
QuestionText: What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape that makes a backwards "L" shape from 2 rectangles.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 11cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 12cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 5cm. The vertical height of the bottom rectangle is labelled 4cm. The left handed rectangle is shaded blue.]()
MisconceptionName: Uses an incorrect side length when splitting a composite shape into parts

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText: Which is the correct point for \( \mathrm{E} \) when reflected in the line \( x=0 \) ? ![A 4 quadrant, coordinate grid with a triangle drawn on it with the coordinates (-4,1) (-1,1) and (-2,3). E is the point (-2,3)]()
MisconceptionName: Rotates instead of reflects

ConstructName: Identify a rhombus from a description of the properties
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie have been asked to give the name of a quadrilateral with four equal sides
Tom says rectangle
Katie says rhombus
Who do you agree with?
MisconceptionName: Believes a rectangle has four equal sides

ConstructName: Identify congruence in shapes other than triangles
QuestionText: Tom and Katie are discussing congruent shapes Tom says these two shapes are congruent ![Two identical 6-sided "L shape" polygons. One of the polygons has been rotated through 90 degrees.]() Katie says these two shapes are congruent ![Two 6-sided "L shape" polygons. One of the polygons has a wider upright section than the other.]() Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes

ConstructName: Identify a unit of length
QuestionText:
Sally has answered a question on perimeter and worked out an answer of \( 120 \).

Behind the star she has written the units that she used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 120 \color{yellow}\bigstar \)
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise inches (") as a unit of length

ConstructName: Complete multi-step mental calculations
QuestionText:
What is the value of:
\(
\frac{54+58}{2}
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not interpret the correct order of operations in a fraction when there is an addition on the numerator

ConstructName: Find missing angles using angles on a straight line
QuestionText: What is the size of angle \( q \) ? ![Two angles on a straight line, one is labelled 62 degrees and the other is q]()
MisconceptionName: Believes angles on a straight line add to 360 degrees

ConstructName: Substitute numbers into a SUVAT equation to work out distance
QuestionText:
\( s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \) What is the value of \( s \) when
a=6 
u=3 
t=4
MisconceptionName: When a variable in an expression has a power, thinks the power applies to the whole expression

ConstructName: Determine the input of a double function machine used to create an algebraic expression
QuestionText: ![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "− 4" written inside it, the next rectangle has "✕ 4" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "8m − 20" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
MisconceptionName: Does not apply the inverse function to every term in an expression

ConstructName: Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
QuestionText:
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![A coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a triangle with the coordinates (-2,3) (-1,4) and (0,3). P is the point (0,3)]()
MisconceptionName: Fails to reflect across mirror line

ConstructName: Solve problems that combine addition or subtraction with multiplication
QuestionText:
Every week for \( 4 \) weeks, Cara buys a magazine for \( £ 6 \) and gets her nails painted for \( £ 28 \).

How much money does Cara spend altogether?
MisconceptionName: Does not interpret the correct order of operations from a worded problem

ConstructName: Calculate the cube root of a number
MisconceptionName: Divides by the order of the root

ConstructName: Identify corresponding angles
QuestionText:
\( \mathrm{M} \) and \( \mathrm{N} \) are the intersections of the line \( X Y \) with the lines \( P Q \) and RS.
Which angle is corresponding to angle MNS? ![A pair of parallel lines pointing up to the left. PQ and RS are the ends of the parallel lines. PQ is on the left of the diagram with Q being the top left.
A red straight line, XY, crosses the parallel lines. X is on the left of the diagram.
Line XY crosses line PQ at a point marked M.
Line XY crosses line RS at a point marked N.
The angle MNS is marked in red.]()
MisconceptionName: Confuses co-interior and corresponding angles

ConstructName: Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable
QuestionText:
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we do the operation inverse to the sign (- if positive, + if negative)

answer: ![A graph with time (sec) on the horizontal axis and distance (m) on the vertical axis. C is plotted below 3 on the horizontal axis and right of -2 on the vertical axis.]()
ConstructName: Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph
QuestionText:
Johan wants to plot a graph to show the distance a ball travels over time.

After \( 2 \) seconds the ball has travelled \( 3 \) metres.

Where on the graph should Johan plot this?
MisconceptionName: When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.

ConstructName: Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction
QuestionText:
Calculate:
\(
\frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{5}
\)
MisconceptionName: when multiplying fractions multiplies by the reciprocal of the 2nd fraction instead

ConstructName: Divide proper fractions in the form: Integer ÷ Fraction
QuestionText:
Calculate
\(
2 \div \frac{1}{5}
\)
MisconceptionName: When dividing fractions, does the reciprocal of the first fraction instead of the second

ConstructName: Write numbers between 0 and 1 in standard form
QuestionText:
Write the following number in standard form:
\[
0.00506
\]
MisconceptionName: When changing a number to standard form omits zero's of significance

ConstructName: Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers
QuestionText: What fraction is the arrow pointing to? ![An image of a numberline with 5 dashes. On the leftmost dash is the number 1/5. On the rightmost dash is the number 3/5. An arrow points to the 4th dash from the left]()
MisconceptionName: When reading a dash on a number line does not take into account the number at the start or the width of each division

ConstructName: Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape
QuestionText: Which shape has the lowest order of rotational symmetry?
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry

ConstructName: Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors
QuestionText: Which of the following describes how to get from point \( P \) to point \( Q \) ? ![Point P and Point Q are marked on a grid. Q is 4 squares to the right and 2 squares above P]()
MisconceptionName: When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original

ConstructName: Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape
QuestionText: What fraction of the rectangle is shaded? ![Rectangle split into 100 equal parts with 27 parts shaded in yellow]()
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to write a fraction - just given an integer answer

ConstructName: Identify a transversal
QuestionText:
Line JK is.. ![A pair of parallel lines are drawn with the arrow on each pointing to the right.
A straight red line, KJ, is drawn so that diagonally crosses both parallel lines.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not know the term transversal

ConstructName: Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons
QuestionText: What do the dashes tell you about the sides of this polygon? ![A hexagon with a dash on each side.]()
MisconceptionName: Misunderstands dashed lines as being the midpoint

ConstructName: Read values off a displacement-time graph
QuestionText:
This graph shows the position of a ball, relative to a fixed point, over time.

Approximately how far away from its starting point is the ball after \( 8 \) seconds? ![A graph showing time (secs) on the horizontal axis and position (m) on the vertical axis. The graph starts at (0,6) travels in a straight line to (8,15), then a straight line to (16,-15) then a straight line to (24,0). ]()
MisconceptionName: Assumes that a graph always starts at the origin

ConstructName: Identify where negative non-integers lie on a number line
QuestionText: Here is a number line: ![A horizontal number-line with 13 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. The 1st dash is labelled with "-6", the 3rd dash is labelled "-4", the 5th dash is labelled "-2", the 7th dash is labelled "0", the 9th dash is labelled "2", the 11th dash is labelled "4" and the 13th dash is labelled "6"    A red arrow, labelled with a question mark is pointing halfway between the 3rd and 4th dashes. ]() Which of the following numbers could be indicated by the arrow?
MisconceptionName: Counts on in the wrong direction on a number line

ConstructName: Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention
QuestionText: Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention? \( c \div(h+4) \)
MisconceptionName: Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order

ConstructName: Calculate the square of a number
QuestionText: What is the value of \( 1^{2} \) ?
MisconceptionName: Adds the index to the number

ConstructName: Prove statements involving positive and negative numbers
QuestionText:
"If \( n \) is a positive integer, then \( (2 n-13)^{3} \) is negative"

Is the above statement always true, sometimes true, or never true?
MisconceptionName: Believes raising a negative number to an odd power will give a positive answer

ConstructName: Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers
QuestionText:
Isaac is trying to solve the equation on the right. \( 15=\frac{1+k}{4} \) Here are his steps. Step \( 1: \) \(
60=1+k
\)

Step \( 2: \) \(
61=k
\) Which steps, if any, are correct?
MisconceptionName: When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.

ConstructName: Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer
QuestionText: ![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +5 going from -1 up to 4]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
MisconceptionName: Believes the number of jumps between two numbers on a numberline represents the sum of those 2 numbers

ConstructName: Can write Roman numerals between 100 and 1000
QuestionText: Which of the following is the correct way to write \( 900 \) using Roman numerals?
MisconceptionName: Thinks that we can use O as zero for place value in Roman numerals

ConstructName: Round non-integers to the nearest 10
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are arguing about rounding.
Jo says \( \mathbf{1 2 0 6 . 9 7 8} \) rounded to the nearest hundred is \( \mathbf{1 2 0 0} \)
Paul says \( \mathbf{1 2 0 6 . 9 7 8} \) rounded to the nearest ten is \( \mathbf{1 2 0 0} \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Rounds down instead of up

ConstructName: Form expressions from situations described in words
QuestionText:
I think of a number. I take away six and then divide the result by three. The answer I get is \( 21 \).
Which of the following equations represents this?
MisconceptionName: Thinks that a number in front of a bracket means divide

ConstructName: Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer
QuestionText:
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{11} \div 3
\)
MisconceptionName: When dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies both the numerator and denominator by the integer

ConstructName: Identify non-prisms from a diagram
QuestionText: Which of the following is a correct name of this shape? ![A 3D shape with 1 square face and 4 triangular faces. 1 triangular face is attached to each side of the square face.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not know the definition of a cone

ConstructName: Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots
QuestionText:
When \( h=15 \) and \( j=3 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
MisconceptionName: Does not realise addition is commutative

ConstructName: Use the nth term rule for descending integer linear sequences to find another term in a the sequence
QuestionText: What is the 11th term of this sequence? \( u_{n}=2-5 n \)
MisconceptionName: When subtracting past zero, adds the absolute values and then writes the answer with a negative sign

ConstructName: Identify corresponding angles
QuestionText: Which of the following are corresponding angles on this diagram? ![Three almost horizontal lines, two marked with arrows. One almost vertical line crossing them. The twelve angles created are marked a-l. ]()
MisconceptionName: Confuses co-interior and corresponding angles

ConstructName: Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c
MisconceptionName: Believes 0 multiplied by a number gives the number

ConstructName: Interpret continuous data using a line graph
QuestionText:
How many months have an average temperature above 23⁰C ? ![A line graph with title "Monthly Average temperatures for Zakynthos, Greece. (⁰C)". 
The x-axis is labelled with the first letter of every month of the year and is titled "Months". 
The y-axis is titled "Average temperature (⁰C)" and the scale is labelled from 18 to 34 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (J, 18), (F, 20), (M, 21), (A, 22), (M, 23), (J, 25), (J, 29), (A, 32), (S, 27), (O, 22), (N, 20), (D, 18).]()
MisconceptionName: Includes a data point with the value, when asked to find the number of data points above a value

ConstructName: Round integers to the nearest 100
QuestionText: What is \( 356,958 \) rounded to the nearest \( 100 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)

ConstructName: Compare real life graphs
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing graphs that show the volume of water
(V) flowing from a kitchen tap over time (t). Tom says this graph shows water flowing at a constant rate ![A sketch of a graph showing V on the y axis and t on the x axis. A line starts at the origin and slopes upwards getting gradually steeper. ]() Katie says this graph shows water flowing at a constant rate ![A sketch of a graph showing V on the y axis and t on the x axis. A horizontal straight line goes from halfway up the y axis straight across the graph. ]() Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes a curve can show a constant rate

ConstructName: Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers
QuestionText:
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
6(m+4)=24
\)
Jo says you can write: \( m+4=4 \)
Paul says you can write: \( 6 m=20 \)
Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Believes you can subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation

ConstructName: Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure
QuestionText: Round \( 0.0735 \) to \( 1 \) significant figure
MisconceptionName: Changes wrong place value column when rounding

ConstructName: Recognise and name an identity
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing identities
Tom says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 5 y+7 \underset{\star}{2} 7+5 y \) Katie says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 5 y-7 \underset{\star} 7-5 y \) Who is correct?
MisconceptionName: Ignores the negative sign when thinking about the value of a term

ConstructName: Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs
QuestionText:
What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(-3<2 x+1<7\)

ConstructName: Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer
MisconceptionName: When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies the denominator instead of the numerator

ConstructName: Understand the limitations of the mean
QuestionText:

\[
5,6,7,8,8,9,11,12,320
\]

QuestionText:
Which symbol makes the following statement correct?
\(
725,912 \quad \square \quad 2,705,291
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not understand inequality notation

ConstructName: Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one
QuestionText: What is the ratio of \( x \) to \( y \) ? ![A triangle. The bottom width is marked '15cm'. One side is split into two parts, one part is called 'x', the other is marked 'y'. A second line goes across the triangle from where the side is split into two parts. It is marked '5cm'. ]()
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n

QuestionText:
Solve this equation, giving all solutions:
\(
3 p^{2}+9=39
\)
MisconceptionName: Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation

QuestionText: Which of the following statements can you prove from this diagram? ![Angles around a point split into three parts with the parts labelled: m+50, 2m+n and 220-2m]()
MisconceptionName: Does not use angle facts when setting up an equation from an angle diagram

ConstructName: Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention
QuestionText: Which of the following is the correct way of writing: \( p \) divided by \( q \), then add \( 3 \) using algebraic convention?
MisconceptionName: Does not account for grammar when writing algebra e.g. ,then making a group

QuestionText:
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
0.2, \quad 0.22, \quad 0.212
\]
MisconceptionName: When calculating the range does not reorder the data to find the largest number minus the smallest number

ConstructName: Raise a positive integer to a positive integer power
QuestionText: Which of the following is a power of \( 5 \) ?

ConstructName: Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10
MisconceptionName: Finds 10% of an amount rather than the percentage being asked

When Sarah completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\[
p^{2}-10 p-1 \equiv(p-5)^{2}  \Delta
\]
MisconceptionName: Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling

ConstructName: Calculate the cube root of a number
MisconceptionName: Halves when asked to find the cube root

\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  0  & \( 7 \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline 1  & \( \) & \( 144 \degree \) \\
\hline 2  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 3  & \( 4 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 4 or more  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 30  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Jenny wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
MisconceptionName: Believes that a fraction means dividing the denominator by the numerator

ConstructName: Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages
QuestionText: What is \( 0.03 \) written as a percentage?
MisconceptionName: Thinks you need to just add a % sign to a decimal to convert to a percentage

answer: ![A graph with a straight line going from bottom left to top right. The graph starts from 0 on the y axis. ]()
ConstructName: Recognise graphical representations of inverse proportion in the form y = k/x
QuestionText: Which of the following graphs show that \( \mathrm{x} \) is inversely proportional to \( y \) ?
MisconceptionName: Confuses the graphs of  direct and inverse proportion

QuestionText: Use the graph to approximate the solution to \( x^{2}-x-6<-4 \) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-x-6 drawn on.]()

ConstructName: Read values off a real life graph
QuestionText:
This graph shows the relationship between journey time and the speed of a car.
How long will the journey take if the car travels at \( 30 \mathrm{mph} \) ? ![A graph showing speed in miles per hour on the x axis and journey time in hours on the y axis. MisconceptionName: When asked to read a value from a graph, thinks they give the corresponding value on the other axis, rather than reading from the graph

QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{5 x-1}{3}=2\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5 x-1=6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5 x}{3}=3 \)

Who is correct?

ConstructName: Find missing angles using angles around a point
QuestionText: What is the size of angle \( z \) ? ![Angles around a point made up of two angles labelled 162 degrees and z]()

answer: ![C points to 'the back' which is the rectangular face coming off the short vertical side of the right angled triangle]()

QuestionText:
Amy wants to calculate the volume of this shape.

MisconceptionName: Thinks cross section of a prism can be any face

QuestionText: Which combination of mathematical instruments has been used to construct this triangle? ![Constructed triangle with two sides and an angle labelled]()
MisconceptionName: Believes constructing a triangle with given SAS requires a compass

answer: ![A bar model showing a bar for Jodie's age as y + 3 which is half the width of her father's bar.  Her father's bar is shown as 2 lots of y + 3, where the first y + 3 + y total to 43.]()

Her father was \( 43 \) years old. This year Jodie is half her father's age.

MisconceptionName: Does not understand bar modelling in algebra

Jane measures the length and width of her rectangular classroom as \( 8.3 \mathrm{~m} \) and \( 12.9 \mathrm{~m} \).
Which calculation will give the best estimate of the area?
MisconceptionName: Rounds down instead of up

A coach takes \( 2 \) hours \( 40 \) minutes to complete a journey from Manchester to Milton Keynes.

MisconceptionName: Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes

MisconceptionName: When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value

MisconceptionName: Hasn't lined up the place value columns when writing out the calculation

QuestionText:
Samia has \( 12 \) cakes to share between \( 5 \) people.
What fraction of a cake does each person get?

answer: ![A column subtraction written as 0.700 - 0.612 with the decimal points lined up.]()
ConstructName: Subtract decimals from integers
QuestionText: How should you line up the digits to calculate \( 7-0.612 \) ?
MisconceptionName: Does not know the units column is before the decimal point

QuestionText: What is the value of A? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-6" below the 2nd dash and "3" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "A" is pointing halfway between the 4th and 5th dashes. ]()
MisconceptionName: When placing a negative number on a number line student assumes numbers with a greater absolute value are placed to the right.

QuestionText:
A group of \( 8 \) friends share \(  £6 \) equally.

MisconceptionName: Thinks the fraction 1/n can express sharing n items between any number of people
